results.title: Man and Donkey lever magic lantern slide
results.brief_description: Magic lantern set effects slide with wooden frame. The coloured slide shows a portrait of a man wearing a hat in a circular slide. An adjustable handle allows the viewer to move a beard.

results.title: Sheep: handle with care. Parts I-III
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development and Bob Scarfe
results.brief_description: A three part program that shows the different aspects of sheep management. Part 1 deals with Mustering, mouthing, teeth trimming, drenching and foot care. Part 2 deals wth crutching, vaccinating, lamb marking and drafting. Part 3 deals with shearing, branding, dipping and jetting

results.title: Water against wildfire
results.creator_credit: Kestrel Films (Australia), Victorian Film Corporation, John Richardson and David Morgan
results.brief_description: This film was made at the request of Victoria’s Forest Commission. Bush fires all over Australia and indeed all parts of the world create havoc not only on the environment of humans but also on the delicate balance of the natural world. A training film directed towards forest workers on how to use water on forest fires and the follow-up after the fire has been contained.

results.title: The Trout harvest
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Victoria. Dept. of Fisheries and Wildlife and Ted Davis
results.brief_description: The Snobs Creek fish hatchery was newly established at this time, and this film shows how the fish are bred from the egg stage to liberation into rivers and lakes. This film was included in the San Francisco Film Festival 1961.

results.title: Vegetable Growing at Home
results.creator_credit: Jack Keane and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: This short film is a government-produced educational film designed to encourage viewers to grow their own vegetables at home during the Second World War. Produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, the film features a suburban couple who receive a brochure in the mail called ‘Wartime Vegetable Growing at Home’. The educational intent of the film is interspersed with comic scenes predicated on the (now outdated) gender roles of the time as the domestic housewife, Mary, sabotages her husband’s plans to play golf and convinces him to start a vegetable garden. With the assistance of the girl next door, a student at the Burnley School of Horticulture, the hapless husband begins transforming his patch of grass and stops sulking. Moving to an instructional section filmed at the Burnley School of Horticulture, the film’s narrator explains how to dig a patch, turn over and rake the soil, and plant seeds, with the process performed by another expert female gardener (despite clearly being a skilled professional, the narrator mocks her for being a woman). The gardener then demonstrates how to thin out young plants, cultivate the soil and deal with pests, with occasional interludes back to the comic scenes of the domestic couple. Finally, the film shows the rewards of growing your own vegetables, with a bountiful harvest from the garden.

results.title: Daybill for the American release of Jedda
results.credit_line: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia.
results.brief_description: Jedda represented a lot of historic firsts for the Australian moving image, not just in the story it was telling but how that story was told. The first fully funded Australian narrative feature to be shot in colour in the country, it used a colour process known as the Belgian Gevacolor so it was possible to shoot on location among the Australian landscape.

results.title: "War Pictures": Australians at the Cinema 1914-1918
results.brief_description:
A compilation of archival films that chronicles the Australian cinema-going experience during WWI from 1914 to 1918.

Between 1914 and 1918, cinema attendance was on the rise and the local film industry was expanding with over 50 Australian feature films produced during the period. While many of these films have been tragically lost, those that remain offer a rare glimpse into Australian life during this turbulent time.

As the war began, filmmakers rushed to make features about Australia’s involvement. Alfred Rolfe’s ‘Hero of the Dardanelles’ (1915) told the story of Gallipoli, complete with landing scenes shot at Tamarama Beach in Sydney.

However, as the years progressed, war-weary audiences lost their taste for patriotic stories, and a new genre of home-grown comedies emerged featuring knockabout characters from the Australian bush. Throughout the war years, Hollywood dramas, serials, love stories and comedies were also staple attractions, and Charlie Chaplin was an international superstar.

War Pictures offers a wide-ranging selection of local and international material, including a focus on Australia’s ‘lost films’.

Specially commissioned introductions and musical accompaniment offer contemporary audiences a chance to step back time and experience cinema as it was enjoyed during the First World War.

This work was shown at ACMI from 10 March to 26 July 2015 in the ‘War Pictures’ exhibition.

results.title: Britain's First Light
results.brief_description:
‘First Light’ is a British wide organisation that uses film and media production to develop skills in young people aged up to 25.
Talented youth from a wide range of backgrounds are provided with training led by film and media industry professionals using industry standard equipment. This collection draws works from several years of this creative partnership.

results.title: Until My Heart's, Like, Finished
results.creator_credit: Peter Snelling, Phil Shepherd, Martin Hodgson, Somerset Film and First Light
results.brief_description: On the day of your 16th birthday, your mum kicks you out of home for good. You live in a car. You sofa surf. You sleep rough. Life for these young people has been tough with many challenges. Here they tell their stories in their own words, reveal they have learnt about how to survive and make plans for putting their lives back together.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Snelling, Phil Shepherd, Martin Hodgson, Somerset Film and First Light
